text: [Music]
I think one of the things that is uh you
know one of the impacts here is that we
have a much higher uh degree of um
informal learning than we used to have.
Uh that's not to say that that formal
learning is declining. It's just to say
that after people have finished their
formal education we have such a greater
opportunity for informal education. uh
35 years ago, you might uh you know read
a a newspaper story about I don't know
uh Albania and you might think hm
Albania I barely barely know anything
about it and I don't know the history.
Uh I should go to the library and look
that up but I mean frankly nobody ever
much went to the library to look things
up. It was you know that's quite a
journey. You have to put aside a lot of
your um energy to go and do something
like that. Whereas now when somebody
wonders about Albania they just type
Albania into a search engine. They get
typically the Wikipedia article. They
get a nice basic history and background
and they can really dig very deep if
they want to follow the sources and and
you can learn a lot. All that kind of
learning I think helps people to become
you know better citizens uh better
decision makers in their own lives. Uh
sometimes it's political but sometimes
it's personal decisions that people
might make that they can make um with a
lot more knowledge than they had in the
past. uh simply because it's so easy to
informally get the basic information
that you
need whatsoever. Um obviously that's not
to say that that the state of
information on the internet is perfect.
It certainly isn't. Uh there's a lot of
problems of uh you know reliability,
accuracy. Uh I think people have a lot
to learn in terms of figuring out what
does make a good source and how do you
know when something is is reliable or
not. Uh but overall, you know, this this
instant access to information is is
almost, you know, completely a good
thing. Um I don't think there's ever uh
you know, any case outside of science
fiction examples where you can say
people are better off not knowing about
the world.
So well so I mean I think there's a lot
of uh steps that we can take um in the
internet community to try to help ensure
the accuracy of the information on the
internet. uh in community projects like
uh Wikipedia or the various Wikia sites
uh the communities tend to um have a
very conservative and old-fashioned view
of what uh information quality looks
like which is sometimes surprising to
people. Uh they sort of assume it's
going to be some crazy MySpace of
information or something. But
realistically uh you know a lot of the
scholarly standards that you would hope
for are exactly what the community
settles on. So things like uh you know
comparing what's written in an article
to what the sources say and judging the
sources by their quality. You know is it
a a book published uh by a Harvard
University press or is it a tabloid
magazine um or is it some random crazy
web page? You know people really do have
a pretty good idea of how to assess the
quality of information. uh and
communities are coming together to
really uh think about these things and
to start to try to build better and
better quality uh information resources.
So yeah, there's a lot of work to do.
[Music]
